metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Rust Arrays
Arrays
Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value.
content.html: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value.

content.text: Create an Array
You can create an array using square brackets [ ] , and separate the values with commas.
content.html: You can create an array using square brackets [ ], and separate the values with commas.

content.text: Note: Make sure all values are of the same data type (integers in the example below):
content.html: Note: Make sure all values are of the same data type (integers in the example below):

content.code_html: let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

content.text: This creates an array with five integers.
content.html: This creates an array with five integers.

content.text: Access Array Elements
To access an array element, refer to its index number.
content.html: To access an array element, refer to its index number.

content.text: Array indexes start with 0: [0] is the first element. [1] is the second element, etc.
content.html: Array indexes start with 0: [0] is the first element. [1] is the second element, etc.

content.text: This statement accesses the value of the first element [ 0 ] in numbers :
content.html: This statement accesses the value of the first element [0] in numbers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("The first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

content.code:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("The first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("The first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

content.code_html:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("The first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("The first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

content.text: Change Array Values
To change the value of a specified element, refer to the index number and assign a new value.
content.html: To change the value of a specified element, refer to the index number and assign a new value.

content.text: Remember to make the array mutable (using the mut keyword):
content.html: Remember to make the array mutable (using the mut keyword):

content.code_html:
let mut numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
numbers[0] = 10;
println!("The new first number is: {}", numbers[0]);

content.text: Array Length
You can get the number of elements in an array using the .len() method:
content.html: You can get the number of elements in an array using the .len() method:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("This array has {} elements.", numbers.len());

content.code:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("This array has {} elements.", numbers.len());

syntax_highlighting.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("This array has {} elements.", numbers.len());

content.code_html:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("This array has {} elements.", numbers.len());

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("This array has {} elements.", numbers.len());

content.text: Loop Through an Array
You can loop through the array elements with the for loop.
content.html: You can loop through the array elements with the for loop.

content.code_html:
let fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"];
for fruit in fruits {
  println!("I like {}.", fruit);
}

content.text: Print the Entire Array
Note: When printing the whole array, you must use {:?} inside println! :
content.html: Note: When printing the whole array, you must use {:?} inside println!:

content.code_html:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("{:?}", numbers);

content.text: If you are just printing one element from the array, you can use {} .
content.html: If you are just printing one element from the array, you can use {}.

content.code_html:
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
println!("{}", numbers[0]);

content.text: To Sum Up:
content.html: To Sum Up:

content.text: When printing a single element from an array, use {} .
content.html: When printing a single element from an array, use {}.

content.text: When printing the entire array, use {:?} .
content.html: When printing the entire array, use {:?}.

content.text: If you are wondering why we didn't use {:?} inside the loop (in the example earlier on this page), it is because in a loop, you are printing each single value from the array. Since each value is a string, {} works. But to print the whole array, you need to use {:?} .
content.html: If you are wondering why we didn't use {:?} inside the loop (in the example earlier on this page), it is because in a loop, you are printing each single value from the array. Since each value is a string, {} works. But to print the whole array, you need to use {:?}.

content.text: A good rule is to use {} for basic types like strings, numbers, and booleans, and {:?} for data structures like arrays and vectors - when printing the entire structure.
content.html: A good rule is to use {} for basic types like strings, numbers, and booleans, and {:?} for data structures like arrays and vectors - when printing the entire structure.

content.text: Fixed Size (Arrays) vs. Dynamic Size (Vectors)
You will often hear the terms fixed size and dynamic size when talking about arrays in Rust.
content.html: You will often hear the terms fixed size and dynamic size when talking about arrays in Rust.

content.text: This is because arrays in Rust have a fixed size , meaning you cannot add or remove elements after the array is created:
content.html: This is because arrays in Rust have a fixed size, meaning you cannot add or remove elements after the array is created:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

content.code_html:
// An array with 3 elements
 let mut cars = ["Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"];

// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will result in an error
 cars[3] = "Mazda";   // Error: index out of bounds

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

content.text: Vectors - Dynamic Size Example
For operations that require adding and removing array elements, you can use Vectors , which are resizable arrays.
content.html: For operations that require adding and removing array elements, you can use Vectors, which are resizable arrays.

content.text: The size of a vector is dynamic, meaning it can grow and shrink as needed.
content.html: The size of a vector is dynamic, meaning it can grow and shrink as needed.

content.text: You can use the vec! macro to create a vector:
content.html: You can use the vec! macro to create a vector:

content.code_html:
// A vector with 3 elements
 let mut cars = vec!["Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"];

// Add another element
 cars.push("Tesla");

println!("{:?}", cars); // ["Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"]

content.text: This was just a short introduction to vectors. You will learn more about them in the next chapter.
content.html: This was just a short introduction to vectors. You will learn more about them in the next chapter.
